Publishing the Bill on Thursday, Mr Michael Gove said: There are areas of Ofsted inspections, such as community cohesion or regulations governing what students bring in in their lunchboxes at lunchtime, which are entirely peripheral. "One of the problems with Ofsted inspections is that they are asked to inspect and measure for things which, by definition, are hard to judge and not central to what schools are about. The Bill hands more control to the Education Secretary to intervene in failing schools. Mr Michael Gove insisted that under-achieving academies will not be exempt from this.
